channel.title: Yahoo! News: Op/Ed
channel.copyright: Copyright (c) 2004 Yahoo! Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Military families cope and hope this Thanksgiving (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Spending time with family, sharing the traditional turkey dinner and taking a moment to give thanks is a simple-enough Thanksgiving Day formula. Unless, that is, you're part of a military family separated from loved ones in Iraq or Afghanistan.

item.title: End of an era (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Perhaps more than his peers at ABC and NBC, Dan Rather has been the face of network news in recent decades. He has anchored The CBS Evening News for 24 years - almost as long as CNN has existed - and he has been a familiar figure since the Kennedy assassination. He has stood out for his folksy witticisms, his take-no-prisoners style, and - most recently - his mistakes.

item.title: BLOGGERS WIN THEIR AIR ATTACK VS. DAN (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - WASHINGTON — CBS anchor Dan Rather's discharge under less than honorable circumstances is the icing on the 2004 election cake for a lot of Republicans who see him as the icon of liberal media bias.

item.title: A RATHER UGLY EXIT (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - Dan Rather announced yesterday that he will retire in March as anchor of the CBS Evening News — though he'll hang on as a correspondent for both editions of "60 Minutes."

item.title: Editorial Roundup (AP)
item.description: AP - Excerpts from editorials in newspapers in the United States and overseas:

item.title: ABC'S NEW HOUSEWIFE PORN (Maggie Gallagher)
item.description: Maggie Gallagher - More than 21 million Americans watched the debut of "Desperate Housewives" on ABC this fall. Millions more saw one of the "Housewives" stars, Nicollette Sheridan, make what Reuters called a "very forward pass" in a promo during NFL's "Monday Night Football" broadcast, leaping apparently (but not visibly) naked into the arms of the Philadelphia Eagles' Terrell Owens in a locker room.

item.title: IF IT'S 2005, IT MUST BE TIME FOR ANOTHER WAR (Ted Rall)
item.description: Ted Rall - Bushies Gear Up for Invading Iran

item.title: STATE OF THE NATION (William F. Buckley)
item.description: William F. Buckley - It is speculated that the president has already got his staff to hammer out preliminary drafts of the State of the Union address, though it will not be delivered until January. I remember in 1966 being seated alongside professor Arthur Schlesinger Jr. in a CBS studio. Our duty was to opine on the State of the Union speech being given by President Lyndon Johnson. He had defeated Barry Goldwater soundly a year before and had recently decided to challenge the North Vietnamese invasion of the South, summoning a great army to service in Indochina.

item.title: THE LOSS THAT KEEPS ON GIVING! (Ann Coulter)
item.description: Ann Coulter - As we wait for CBS to concede the election, Democrats are claiming Kerry lost because Americans are stupid -- and if there's one thing voters respond to, it's crude insults.

item.title: THE ARGUMENT FOR CUTTING AND RUNNING (Richard Reeves)
item.description: Richard Reeves - NEW YORK -- This, I expect and others hope, is my last column on the specifics of the 2004 presidential election. After Election Day, I found my thoughts going back to something that happened during a panel discussion I moderated for The New York Observer in October. I mentioned then that I once asked a presidential candidate what was the worst part of running, and he said: "All the lying you have to do."

item.title: DON'T GIVE THANKS FOR ALL THAT FAT (Cynthia Tucker)
item.description: Cynthia Tucker - The velvet-voiced Ruben Studdard, last year's "American Idol" winner, has a simple plan for the holidays: to eat heartily of the down-home soul food he likes so much.

item.title: BUSH'S SECOND TERM WELL UNDER WAY WITH NEW FACES, NEW ROLES (David Shribman)
item.description: David Shribman - The president doesn't start his second term for another two months, but that's a technicality. The first term ended this month, and the new Bush era has already begun.

item.title: TURKEY MOVES CLOSER TO E.U. MEMBERSHIP (Georgia Anne Geyer)
item.description: Georgia Anne Geyer - WASHINGTON -- Earlier this fall, at the bureaucratic, utilitarian offices of the European Union in downtown Brussels, a scene unfolded that was historic and filled with pathos.

item.title: 'DON'T IMPOSE YOUR VALUES' ARGUMENT IS BIGOTRY IN DISGUISE (John Leo)
item.description: John Leo - I am struggling to understand the "don't impose your values" argument. According to this popular belief, it is wrong, and perhaps dangerous, to vote your moral convictions unless everybody else already shares them. Of course if everybody already shares them, no imposition would be necessary.

item.title: WHAT MAKES NEWSPAPERS GOOD (Gerald Boyd)
item.description: Gerald Boyd - My professional life has been newspapers. That experience has resulted in a love affair that is hard for many readers to understand. Unless you adore the distinct odor that printer's ink creates, or the controlled newsroom chaos when a big story breaks, or the adrenalin high as a deadline approaches, you probably see me as nuts.

item.title: CHATTER BUS (Randy Cohen)
item.description: Randy Cohen - On the noisy $10 Chinatown bus from New York to Boston, the girl behind me spent the entire four hours on her cellphone, telling the same inane story to five different people. I wanted to ask her to stop, but I didn't know if I should, considering the price of the ride and that I don't mind noise in general, just her nasal, repetitive noise. What should I have done? -- Justine van der Leun, New York

item.title: MONSTER OF A LAWYER (Ted Rall)
item.description: Ted Rall - Nominee for Attorney General Even Worse Than Ashcroft

item.title: DUMB BRIGHT GUYS (William F. Buckley)
item.description: William F. Buckley - When Robert Bork was a professor at Yale Law School, he had a telephone call from the young editor of the Yale Daily News, who was in a tizzy. The paper was going to press with its findings on the faculty vote in the upcoming election, President Lyndon Johnson vs. Sen. Barry Goldwater. The editor explained that the paper was kind of embarrassed: As things stood, the next day's edition would reveal that only a single member of the Yale faculty (of approximately 1,000) was going to vote for Barry Goldwater on Tuesday.

item.title: CONFESSIONS OF A CULTURAL ELITIST (Ted Rall)
item.description: Ted Rall - Win or Lose, Kerry Voters Are Smarter Than Bush Voters

item.title: WHEE TIME! (William F. Buckley)
item.description: William F. Buckley - So it will be Condoleezza Rice. We must deny the temptation to ruffles and flourishes which, heaven knows, one might revel in for a good hour. A woman! An African-American! An academic! Who had a high post at a tough, competitive major university! And -- mirabile dictu -- a conservative!

item.title: NOW KISSING IS THE CRIME OF THE CENTURY (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - THE Italian Anti-Defa mation League needs to act with the speed of a bullet.

item.title: Thanks to her, the world changed (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Thanksgiving is the traditional day we show gratitude for what we have in America - our freedom, our principles, the bounty we have been given in our lives.

item.title: GUILTY, DISGUSTED, AMERICAN (Ted Rall)
item.description: Ted Rall - NEW YORK--How interesting, Democrats watching the election results at a high-rise hotel in midtown Manhattan commented, that the rest of America thinks it understands terrorism better than we do. New York bore the brunt of 9/11 yet CNN's exit poll found that New Yorkers considered Iraq a bigger issue than terrorism when casting their votes for president.

item.title: YOUR RIGHTS, THEIR RIGHTS (William F. Buckley)
item.description: William F. Buckley - We hear the clamor in the matter of the Patriot Act and other measures especially associated with retiring Attorney General John Ashcroft. Just rubbing a hand lightly over U.S. history reminds us that these questions arose in the past, notoriously with the Alien and Sedition Acts of 1798. Abraham Lincoln liked to have his own way when pressures were rife, and of course he suspended habeas corpus, to the dismay of members of his own Cabinet and the judge who gave us Dred Scott.

item.title: GUY WEASELS A WEEK (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - Former Albany powerhouse Guy Ve lella owes the people of the state of New York nine more months behind bars on plea-bargained bribe-taking charges — and he won't pay up.

item.title: As you travel this holiday, relish the nation's blessings (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - You'd have to be a pretty cynical creature not to enjoy Thanksgiving.

item.title: JOHN KERRY FOR PRESIDENT (Ted Rall)
item.description: Ted Rall - Patriots Reject Bush "Reelection"

item.title: WARGAMING IRAN (William F. Buckley)
item.description: William F. Buckley - If you can do it, forget Fallujah for just a minute. Think Iran (never mind its negotiations with the Europeans). A productive way to do this is to read James Fallows in the current issue of The Atlantic Monthly. The title of the article is, "Will Iran Be Next?" The subtitle gives away the conclusions, and so will here be suppressed.

item.title: CLINTON'S LIE-BRARY (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - LITTLE CROCK, Ark. — Our neediest president has out done even himself. Bill Clinton has chosen not to roll into history with his chin up and his pants zipped. He's staging an eternal hissy fit.

item.title: Bill ignores critical issues (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - The 9/11 reform bill is currently snagged by the Senate's refusal to address three critical issues: Should states continue to issue driver's licenses to illegal aliens? Should we tighten our asylum system that terrorists exploited to such deadly effect? Have we ensured the military chain of command is not broken in our intelligence restructuring?

item.title: OPENHANDEDNESS BY BUSH (William F. Buckley)
item.description: William F. Buckley - A friend -- a born-again Republican -- asks just what might President Bush do to live up to his promise to represent all the American people. It is natural, if one has only recently joined the communion of saints, to worry about persistent sinners. What can Mr. Bush do to win their confidence? To make them feel better?

item.title: AN EGO BIGGER THAN THE GARDEN (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - Jim Dolan, who owns Madison Square Garden, desperately wants to run with the big dogs in New York's entertainment world.

item.title: 2 congressmen think small, leaving nation at risk (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - When the nation is under attack, citizens normally rally together. Differences are set aside to pursue common goals.

item.title: WE DIDN'T TELL YOU SO (William F. Buckley)
item.description: William F. Buckley - Those of us in the trade get asked the question (inevitably), "Who do you think is going to win?" Years ago I embarked on the most tedious bout of prolonged honesty by replying, "I don't really know." Inevitably the questioner suspected I was holding something back. I wasn't -- except, this time, on the final day. On Nov. 1, I received two communications, privately tendered, that I attached meaning to.

item.title: SEINFELD & GANG IN A 'REUNION' ABOUT NOTHING (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - THE rumors of a "Seinfeld" reunion have been greatly exaggerated.

item.title: Amend it, but not just for Arnold (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - It is the most glaring contradiction in our Constitution: a nation of immigrants that excludes anyone who is not born in the United States from becoming president. While long criticized, it went largely unchallenged until Arnold Schwarzenegger became governor of California and his fans discovered that he couldn't become "The Presinator" because of his Austrian birth.

item.title: PARTING THOUGHTS (William F. Buckley)
item.description: William F. Buckley - For just about 24 hours, the people of the United States will be happy and at peace. That will be between 10 p.m. on Monday, Nov. 1, and approximately 10 p.m. on Tuesday, Nov. 2. We'll be happy because the carping will have stopped, and the guns of litigation will not have begun to fire. These fusillades will begin when the television blinkers register "Undecided," referring to voters in Michigan or Florida, or Ohio, or Colorado.

item.title: MIKE'S CHALLENGE (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - Mayor Bloomberg got awfully testy recently when his commitment to reforming New York City's teachers contract was called into question.

item.title: Congress' overstuffed turkey (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - While Congress couldn't manage to address urgent terrorism issues before leaving town, it had a grand old time at its annual porkfest - rolling the nation ever deeper into debt to pay for dubious local projects.

item.title: ALGERIA WARNED US (William F. Buckley)
item.description: William F. Buckley - In 1978, the British historian Sir Alistair Horne published a book on the Algerian war called "A Savage War of Peace." At a single event, later that year, both Arthur Schlesinger Jr. and John Kenneth Galbraith pronounced it the best book, in their estimation, published during the year. And quite recently, an observer noted that Israel's General Sharon keeps a copy of it for bedside reading. Indeed, the observer heard the general say that if he had been Charles de Gaulle, he'd have ripped the FLN -- the Algerian nationalist force -- apart.

item.title: DON'T LET THIS COLLEGE-EDUCATED KILLER FOOL YOU (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - YOU would certainly get a November surprise if you ever heard Anthony Rotondo use words like: "deese, dems or dos."

item.title: Women's sexual health deserves equal attention (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - A recent study found that a heart medication reduced the death rate among black patients, while whites saw no benefit. With this finding, the national dialogue exploded. By proving success in an exclusively black population, the drug's maker has virtually guaranteed approval by the Food and Drug Administration. Some medical ethicists say whites were left behind, while others contend there's nothing wrong with race-tailored medication.

item.title: KOFI'S CASH LAUNDRY . . . (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - When French bank BNP Paribas was jockeying to win the United Na tions bank account for Saddam's Oil-for-Food program, it's not likely that its sales pitch was: "The job is so easy, a monkey could do it."

item.title: FDA's system works (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - The Food and Drug Administration takes drug safety and risks seriously and will continue its longstanding practice of assessing the safety of drugs using sound judgment and good science - including peer-reviewed analyses.

item.title: A CASE OF HIT AND MISS (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - AS a tough, honorable cop, Ken McCabe was a credit to the NYPD.

item.title: Does another Vioxx lurk among your prescriptions? (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - David Graham is a man you might want to listen to - at least if you have any concern about the safety of the prescription drugs in your medicine cabinet.

item.title: ENEMY PROPAGANDA (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - Get set for another round of America- bashing — this time over charges that a U.S. Marine shot to death an apparently disarmed, wounded terrorist inside a mosque in Fallujah.

item.title: A good defense alone won't win bioterrorism war (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - In the world of sports, we hear that "defense wins championships." But is this true?

item.title: RIGHT WRONG TO GLOAT AS MR. CAUTION EXITS, STAGE LEFT (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - THE coverage of Colin Powell's resignation as secretary of state has been uniformly celebratory, which is appropriate. Powell is one of the great public servants of our time, a man who served his country in war and peace with extraordinary honor as a soldier and a statesman.

item.title: For boomers, it's all about them (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - How much of the antagonism between Disney CEO Michael Eisner and former No. 2 Michael Ovitz is really over money?

item.title: CALLING CONDOLEEZZA (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - The departure of Secretary of State Colin Powell, announced yesterday in Washington, was both expected and necessary.

item.title: Flagrant fouls (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - National Basketball Association players will likely think hard before charging into the stands after fans again, no matter the cause.

item.title: CHUCK AND SPITZER NIX PEACE BID (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - HUSH-HUSH at tempts to broker a "summit meet ing" between U.S. Sen. Charles Schumer and Attorney General Eliot Spitzer in hopes of avoiding a potentially divisive primary for governor have failed, The Post has learned.

item.title: A racy TV promo gets iced, and so does 'Private Ryan' (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Not since a "wardrobe malfunction" during the 2004 Super Bowl gave viewers a peek at Janet Jackson's breast has the dropping of a piece of cloth caused so much uproar.

item.title: THROTTLING FREE SPEECH (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - Not content that the First Amendment still has some life, Sen. John McCain is going to try again to kill it.

item.title: Can 'family' disagree but preserve unity? (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - It's called the most exclusive club in the world. The United States Senate. Limited to 100 members, two from each state.

item.title: ED. BIGS' HOTEL SPREE (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - THE new math being prac ticed by school executives could slam taxpayers with a $2.4 million bill from the plush Brooklyn Marriott.

item.title: Protect young eyes and ears (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - ABC's Monday Night Football opener is an excellent example of why simply changing the channel or turning off the TV is not a viable option for the viewing public.

item.title: BUSH'S NEXT AG (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - In choosing White House Counsel Al berto Gonzalez to succeed John Ash croft as attorney general, President Bush selected someone he trusts.

item.title: President is crafting 'harmonious' team (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Jacob Heilbrunn, Los Angeles Times, in a column: "With the departures of (Secretary of State Colin) Powell and his deputy, Richard Armitage, the State Department, long seen by the administration's hawks as an alien force that is pro-Arab and anti-Israel, is going to be turned upside down. ... Will the continued sway of the neocons lead (President) Bush into fresh disasters? Hardly. I predict Bush will successfully stabilize Iraq and that the election there will surprise the world by being conducted openly and fairly. In all, he is far better off relying on the neocons than a crabbed, amoral realist doctrine. ... In fact, the administration is in the process of creating the most harmonious foreign-policy team in decades."

item.title: FIREBRAND FOOL WENT OUT WITH A WHIMPER (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - THE terrorist who vowed martyrdom met an ignominious end ? he died with his boots off.

item.title: When saving lives, color doesn't matter (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - I was fascinated by the report last week that in a study co-sponsored by the Association of Black Cardiologists and a drugmaker, a combination of two drugs led to a 43% decrease in the death rate from heart disease of African-Americans.

item.title: HOPE FOR THE WORLD . . . (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - The world woke up yesterday not merely to the death of Yasser Arafat, but to a whole new Middle East — indeed, a whole new world.

item.title: Onstage, there's no trouble with unity (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - The torrents of rain that dampened the opening of Bill Clinton's presidential library provided an obvious metaphor for Democrats' post-election mood. But the televised festivities in Little Rock also conveyed a deeper and more lasting message.

item.title: Champion for girls sports deserves a win in court (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Roderick Jackson is a basketball coach who believes in fair play. Too bad for him. Thinking that way got him fired. It also landed him Tuesday at the U.S. Supreme Court, which will decide whether the law protects him for doing the right thing.

item.title: Men on the Move (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Four men who symbolize U.S. security, media, pop culture and "the bad guy" are all on the move out, over and off the radar.

item.title: 'GIVES ME CREEPS' (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - THE mother of poor, pretty, murdered Jennifer Levin is afraid. And angry. But she's not one bit surprised that Robert Chambers, who killed her daughter — then blamed the victim for her own death — has again been busted.

item.title: ANOTHER HERO (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - New York City today grieves for one of its Bravest — killed in action thousands of miles from home.

item.title: A CONSTITUTIONAL CASE FOR MEDICAL MARIJUANA (Maggie Gallagher)
item.description: Maggie Gallagher - Hard cases make bad law, the old adage goes. But in the case of Ashcroft v. Raich, the medical marijuana case recently argued before the U.S. Supreme Court, the opposite may turn out to be true: A hard case may lead to a revival of a key principle of constitutional government: Congress has only limited powers over the states.

item.title: THEY FIGHT AND DIE, BUT NOT FOR THEIR COUNTRY (Ted Rall)
item.description: Ted Rall - Why Soldiers Make the Ultimate Sacrifice

item.title: CULTURE CLASH (William F. Buckley)
item.description: William F. Buckley - It is disappointing, for those of us alternately engaged in teaching Iraqis how to square off democratically on divisive issues of state, to sit down and disconnect the telephone, intending to spend a few uninterrupted hours on the issue argued on Monday before the Supreme Court. The issue, of course, is whether individual states can legislate with regard to drug laws if the federal government has already staked out a position on the matter.

item.title: 'IT'S WABBIT SEASON!' (Ann Coulter)
item.description: Ann Coulter - Admittedly, still reeling from the nastiest Democratic campaign since sorority rush at sniper school, the country could do with a little civility. But victorious Republicans behave like Warner Bros. gophers Mac 'n' Tosh: "Awfully sorry, old boy." "No, not at all -- after you." There's something to be said for coming out swinging. We won! The nation is lousy with red states! It's wabbit season!

item.title: MIDDLE-INCOME FAMILIES ARE FEELING THE SQUEEZE (Cynthia Tucker)
item.description: Cynthia Tucker - Sears and Kmart may be struggling for survival in the Darwinian world of retail, but makers of high-end items are managing quite well, it seems. Jimmy Choo is expanding, opening new stores around the globe.

item.title: GETTYSBURG'S MESSAGES WORTH SAVING IN ITS BATTLEFIELDS (David Shribman)
item.description: David Shribman - GETTYSBURG, Pa. -- Things change, even here. The orchard that used to sit beside the Trostle Barn, site of brutal fighting on the second day of the Battle of Gettysburg, is gone. The cherry, pear and peach trees, which the fabled 12th New Hampshire used as cover during an artillery duel, have disappeared. The thicket that once sat on the Neinstedt Field, where Union infantry units established positions, grew into mature trees.

item.title: EASING THE MULE DOWN FROM THE MINARET (Georgia Anne Geyer)
item.description: Georgia Anne Geyer - WASHINGTON -- There's an old Arab proverb about the mule and the minaret: "If you lead your mule to the top of the minaret," it says, "then you must lead him down again."

item.title: OPEN MOUTH, INSERT FOOT (John Leo)
item.description: John Leo - It's time for the 2004 awards for over-the-top rhetoric.

item.title: PAY FOR NO PLAY? (Randy Cohen)
item.description: Randy Cohen - Every day an unkempt man stands outside the grocery store I manage, singing and playing guitar for tips. His playing is monotonous, his voice is a foghorn and customers have complained. Another area store paid him to keep away. Now he's "ready to make a deal" with our store -- in effect, threatening us with more loud attempts at Neil Young songs until we submit. What should I do? -- Troy Bond, Seattle

item.title: IF IT'S 2005, IT MUST BE TIME FOR ANOTHER WAR (Ted Rall)
item.description: Ted Rall - Bushies Gear Up for Invading Iran

item.title: JUST SAY NO (William F. Buckley)
item.description: William F. Buckley - There is reason, every now and then, to be grateful for the development of women's power. Sometimes it is exerted zanily (why are Boy Scouts more celebrated than Girl Scouts?). But they are mobilizing fast on one of the great national idiocies, which is the federal government's airport security practices designed to protect us against another 9/11.

item.title: STATE OF THE NATION (William F. Buckley)
item.description: William F. Buckley - It is speculated that the president has already got his staff to hammer out preliminary drafts of the State of the Union address, though it will not be delivered until January. I remember in 1966 being seated alongside professor Arthur Schlesinger Jr. in a CBS studio. Our duty was to opine on the State of the Union speech being given by President Lyndon Johnson. He had defeated Barry Goldwater soundly a year before and had recently decided to challenge the North Vietnamese invasion of the South, summoning a great army to service in Indochina.

item.title: SPITZER'S MISPLACED FIX (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - As confessed influence-peddler Guy Velella caught another stay of exe cution yesterday, state Attorney General (and governor-presumptive) Eliot Spitzer proposed dealing with corruption in high places by taking a slap at the First Amendment.

item.title: Writing a wrong (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - With sliding expectations for writing in schools, high school graduates are applying to college and entering the workforce lacking basic skills to write application essays and cover letters. Only a quarter of America's 12th-graders, the 2002 National Assessment of Educational Progress found, can write tolerable essays. Only about 2% create the kind of zesty prose that makes reading worthwhile.

item.title: BESIEGED PATAKI EYES REFORM (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - GOV. PATAKI, under increasing attack for weak leadership and a lack of interest in state government, may soon launch his own campaign to "reform" the state, The Post has learned.

item.title: Blacks must tackle AIDS on road toward social equity (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Here in the United States, women are also increasingly affected by HIV/AIDS, and race is a major risk factor: African-American women are more than 23 times as likely as white women to be diagnosed with AIDS, and the disease is now the leading cause of death among black women ages 24 to 35.

item.title: MIKE WINS BIG . . . (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - Score a giant local victory for one of the most successful programs in the nation: welfare reform.

item.title: Dollar slides, alarms ring (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Anyone who has traveled abroad recently knows that it has become a wallet-bruising experience. The dollar is at its lowest level against the euro, the currency of 12 European countries, since it was introduced in 1999. It's off against other major currencies as well, making everything from hotels to parking tolls more expensive.

item.title: HOW I'M TAKING 'EASY WAY' OUT OF CIG HELL (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - MY name is Sara Nelson, and I am a smoker. Not a big smoker, but also not a "chipper" — you know, somebody who smokes one cigarette at a party once a year and forgets about it the rest of the time.

item.title: Must the ill be made to suffer for such meager gain? (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Angel Raich is ill - very ill. She's subject to severe, debilitating pain from an inoperable brain tumor and more than a dozen other ailments, including a chronic wasting condition. Without effective medication, she can't walk, play with her children or sleep.

item.title: MS. SPELLINGS (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - President Bush's nomination of Margaret Spellings to replace Rod Paige as secretary of Educa tion may well cement Dubya's legacy on education reform: missed opportunities.

item.title: Presidential losers left with nowhere to go (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - No sooner had the smoke cleared from the 2004 presidential election than names began to be floated for both parties' presidential nominees for 2008.

item.title: A HOLIDAY SALUTE TO MY NIECE & HERO (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - SGT. Heather Rudolph had a pressing engagement around the globe this Thanksgiving. Her place at our table was empty. But she did find the time to send a message home from Iraq.

item.title: Shift is no cause for alarm (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - America needs a stable dollar to act as a global storehouse of value while allowing the U.S. to compete internationally. We don't need an overvalued dollar like the one that priced our goods out of world markets, tripled our trade deficit and resulted in considerable job losses between 1997 and 2002.

item.title: THE VELELLA CONSPIRACY (New York Post)
item.description: New York Post - Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau must feel like a chump after the big fish he reeled in — former Bronx GOP boss Guy Velella — wiggled out of his 1-year sentence for bribe-taking after just 100 days.

item.title: Troubling exit for NAACP's Mfume (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - The NAACP, this nation's oldest and largest civil rights group, is undergoing another seismic change - one that threatens its claim to leadership of the continuing struggle for racial equality.

item.title: FAA flies blind to risks (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Report finds troubling gaps in oversight of outsourcing system.

item.title: Is democracy Russia's future? Putin again raises doubts (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - The way Russian President Vladimir Putin's behaving these days, you'd think the bad old days of the Soviet Union were coming back with a vengeance. And that raises the question: Is Putin's idea of democracy really democratic, or is it a facade?

item.title: Sweet 16: Not for driving (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Two weeks ago, after a 16-year-old student at Churchill High School in Montgomery County, Md., was killed while driving from a party where alcohol was being served, parents met to discuss how to stop teen drinking and driving.

item.title: Program enhances safety (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - 'Designees' multiply FAA resources and tap private expertise.

item.title: Don't let life fade to black (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - The movie version of the popular children's book, The Polar Express, steamed into theaters earlier this month, and kids are once again becoming entranced by the magic of the Arctic. But the untamed wilderness that has captured the imagination of explorers, and is the home of Christmas legend and the realm of the polar bear is quietly slipping away, even though the means to protect it lie well within our grasp.

item.title: From road rage to fan rage, civility takes a beating (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - When professional athletes start slugging fans, severe penalties pretty much are a no-brainer. So few tears will be shed for the nine basketball players suspended - at the cost of millions in salary - after last week's Detroit Pistons-Indiana Pacers melee, which has since dominated sports pages.

item.title: A new view of AIDS (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Remember AIDS, circa 1990? As it ravaged mainly gay communities in the U.S., a high-volume scramble was on for effective treatments and perhaps even a cure. Contrast that with today. AIDS has dropped off the domestic political radar screen.

item.title: Let's not overreact (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Nobody is proud of last Friday night's brawl during the Indiana Pacers-Detroit Pistons game, but let's not go off the deep end in terms of proposed remedies. Basketball is the nation's most intimate spectator sport, as a result of courtside seating, and for virtually all of its amateur and professional history, violence has been a rarity.

item.title: Holidays serve recipe for diet disaster (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - For most Americans, the holiday season marks an escalation in our battle with the bulge. In fact, you might want to put down that pie you're having for breakfast before you read this: Studies have shown that most of a person's total weight gain over a year occurs during the six weeks between Thanksgiving and New Year's.

item.title: Why are newspapers so popular in Japan? (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Memo to U.S. newspaper owners, publishers and editors: If you publish more news, are fair and polite to friend and foe alike, maybe you can charge more for your newspapers and still sell more of them.

item.title: Disney trial offers rich lessons in corporate governance (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - This weekend marks the transition between the gratitude of Thanksgiving and the greedy excess of Christmas shopping. What better time to muse on the implications of the Disney trial that is providing holiday entertainment in Delaware Chancery Court.
